Description: Verify that the login form is protected against SQL injection attacks
Test Steps: 1. Navigate to https://demowebshop.tricentis.com 2. Click on 'Log in' link 3. Enter test data from Test Data section in Email and Password fields 4. Click 'Log in' button 5. Observe the system response 6. Check browser console and network tab for errors 7. Verify if unauthorized access is granted
Test Data: POSITIVE: Email: valid.user@example.com; Password: ValidPassword123! (should login successfully) | NEGATIVE: Test Case A - Basic SQL Injection: Email: admin' OR '1'='1; Password: ' OR '1'='1; Test Case B - Union Attack: Email: admin' UNION SELECT * FROM users--; Password: any; Test Case C - Comment Attack: Email: admin'--; Password: any; Test Case D - Drop Table Attack: Email: admin'; DROP TABLE users--; Password: any
Expected Result: POSITIVE: 1. User successfully logs in with valid credentials 2. Redirected to homepage or dashboard 3. User session established | NEGATIVE: Test Case A - Login fails with error: 'Login was unsuccessful', No unauthorized access, No database errors exposed; Test Case B - Attack blocked, generic error message, System remains stable; Test Case C - Attack blocked, login fails, No SQL errors in response; Test Case D - Attack blocked, system protected, Database remains intact, No data loss

Description: Verify that the search functionality is protected against XSS (Cross-Site Scripting) attacks
Test Steps: 1. Navigate to https://demowebshop.tricentis.com 2. Locate the search box in the header 3. Enter test data from Test Data section in search field 4. Click 'Search' button or press Enter 5. Observe the search results page 6. Check if script executes (alert popup appears) 7. Verify how search term is displayed 8. Check browser console for errors
Test Data: POSITIVE: Search Term: 'book' (normal search, should return results) | NEGATIVE: Test Case A - Script Tag: ; Test Case B - Image Tag: ; Test Case C - SVG Tag:
Expected Result: POSITIVE: 1. Search results page loads successfully 2. Relevant products displayed 3. Search term displayed as plain text 4. No script execution | NEGATIVE: Test Case A - Script does NOT execute, No alert popup, Search term HTML encoded; Test Case B - Image tag does NOT execute, No alert popup, Safe rendering; Test Case C - SVG tag does NOT execute, No alert popup, Input sanitized; Test Case D - JavaScript protocol blocked, No script execution, Safe handling; Test Case E - HTML entities properly encoded, No script execution, Safe display

Description: Verify that the system prevents unauthorized access attempts and authentication bypass
Test Steps: 1. Navigate to https://demowebshop.tricentis.com 2. Verify user is not logged in 3. Attempt to access protected pages directly via URL using Test Data 4. Observe system response for each attempt 5. Check if pages are accessible without authentication 6. Verify redirect behavior
Test Data: POSITIVE: After valid login, access protected URLs: /customer/info, /order/history (should be accessible when authenticated) | NEGATIVE: Test Case A - Direct URL Access: Try /customer/info without login; Test Case B - URL Manipulation: Try /customer/info?user=admin; Test Case C - Parameter Injection: Try /order/history?id=1' OR '1'='1; Test Case D - Directory Traversal: Try /customer/../admin/; Test Case E - Session Hijacking: Use expired/invalid session token
Expected Result: POSITIVE: 1. Protected pages accessible after valid login 2. User data displayed correctly 3. All features functional | NEGATIVE: Test Case A - Redirected to login page, Error message: 'Please sign in', No data exposed; Test Case B - URL manipulation blocked, Redirected to login, No unauthorized access; Test Case C - Parameter injection blocked, Safe error handling, No SQL execution; Test Case D - Directory traversal blocked, Access denied, Safe redirect; Test Case E - Invalid session rejected, Redirected to login, Session validation enforced

Description: Verify that the system enforces strong password policies and validates password security
Test Steps: 1. Navigate to https://demowebshop.tricentis.com/register 2. Fill in registration form with valid data except password 3. Enter password from Test Data section 4. Click 'Register' button 5. Observe system response 6. Verify error messages or success
Test Data: POSITIVE: Strong Password: Test123!@# (meets all requirements: uppercase, lowercase, number, special char, min length) | NEGATIVE: Test Case A - Weak Password: '123' or 'password'; Test Case B - Short Password: 'Ab1' (less than minimum); Test Case C - No Uppercase: 'test123!@#'; Test Case D - No Lowercase: 'TEST123!@#'; Test Case E - No Number: 'TestPassword!@#'; Test Case F - No Special Character: 'Test1234'; Test Case G - Common Password: 'Password123'
Expected Result: POSITIVE: 1. Password accepted 2. Registration succeeds 3. User account created 4. Success message displayed | NEGATIVE: Test Case A - Error: 'Password is too weak', Registration blocked; Test Case B - Error: 'Password must be at least X characters', Registration blocked; Test Case C - Error: 'Password must contain uppercase letter', Registration blocked; Test Case D - Error: 'Password must contain lowercase letter', Registration blocked; Test Case E - Error: 'Password must contain a number', Registration blocked; Test Case F - Error: 'Password must contain special character', Registration blocked; Test Case G - Error: 'Password is too common', Registration blocked

Description: Verify that user sessions are properly managed and timeout after inactivity
Test Steps: 1. Navigate to https://demowebshop.tricentis.com and log in 2. Verify user is logged in 3. Note the current time 4. Perform actions based on Test Data scenario 5. Observe system response 6. Verify session status 7. Check if user is logged out
Test Data: POSITIVE: Active Session: Log in and use website normally within session timeout period (should remain logged in) | NEGATIVE: Test Case A - Session Timeout: Leave browser idle for 30+ minutes, then try to access protected page; Test Case B - Concurrent Sessions: Log in from multiple browsers/devices; Test Case C - Session Fixation: Capture session token and try to reuse after logout; Test Case D - Session Hijacking: Use stolen session cookie; Test Case E - Session Replay: Reuse old session token
Expected Result: POSITIVE: 1. Session remains active during normal usage 2. User can access all features 3. No unexpected logouts | NEGATIVE: Test Case A - Session expires after timeout, Redirected to login, Message: 'Your session has expired'; Test Case B - Multiple sessions handled correctly, Each session independent, No conflicts; Test Case C - Session invalidated after logout, Old token rejected, New login required; Test Case D - Stolen session rejected, Security validation enforced, Access denied; Test Case E - Old session token rejected, Token expiration enforced, Re-authentication required

Test Case Title: Sensitive Data Exposure in URLs and Forms
Description: Verify that sensitive information is not exposed in URLs, form data, or error messages
Test Steps: 1. Navigate to https://demowebshop.tricentis.com 2. Open browser Developer Tools (F12) 3. Go to 'Network' tab 4. Perform actions from Test Data section 5. Monitor network requests 6. Check URLs, headers, response data 7. Verify sensitive data visibility 8. Check error messages
Test Data: POSITIVE: Normal Usage: Log in, add products, checkout using valid data (sensitive data should be encrypted/secure) | NEGATIVE: Test Case A - Password in URL: Check if password appears in URL parameters during login; Test Case B - Credit Card in URL: Check if payment info appears in URL; Test Case C - Error Message Exposure: Trigger error and check if database structure exposed; Test Case D - Response Header Leak: Check response headers for server version, framework details; Test Case E - Plain Text Password: Check if password sent in plain text (should be encrypted)
Expected Result: POSITIVE: 1. Passwords encrypted in transmission 2. Sensitive data not in URLs 3. Error messages generic 4. Headers don't expose system info | NEGATIVE: Test Case A - Password NOT in URL, Uses POST method, Secure transmission; Test Case B - Payment info NOT in URL, Secure handling, Encrypted transmission; Test Case C - Error messages generic, No database structure exposed, No SQL queries shown; Test Case D - Headers don't expose server version, No framework details, No internal IPs; Test Case E - Password encrypted/hashed, HTTPS used, Secure transmission

Description: Verify that the application is protected against CSRF attacks by implementing proper tokens
Test Steps: 1. Navigate to https://demowebshop.tricentis.com and log in 2. Open browser Developer Tools (F12) 3. Navigate to forms from Test Data section 4. Inspect HTML source for CSRF tokens 5. Verify token presence and format 6. Attempt form submission scenarios from Test Data 7. Observe system response
Test Data: POSITIVE: Valid CSRF Token: Submit form with valid CSRF token (should succeed) | NEGATIVE: Test Case A - Missing CSRF Token: Submit form without CSRF token; Test Case B - Invalid CSRF Token: Submit form with modified/expired token; Test Case C - Token Reuse: Try to reuse same token for multiple submissions; Test Case D - Cross-Origin Request: Attempt form submission from different origin; Test Case E - Token Mismatch: Submit form with token from different session
Expected Result: POSITIVE: 1. Forms contain CSRF tokens 2. Tokens unique per session 3. Form submission succeeds with valid token 4. Token validated on server | NEGATIVE: Test Case A - Form rejected, Error: 'Invalid security token', Submission blocked; Test Case B - Invalid token rejected, Error message displayed, Form submission fails; Test Case C - Token reuse blocked, Each submission requires new token, Security enforced; Test Case D - Cross-origin blocked, Same-origin policy enforced, Request rejected; Test Case E - Token mismatch detected, Session validation enforced, Submission rejected
